div.p: In 1950, 400,000 lions roamed Africa. Today, fewer than 40,000 are left. Why? There are a few reasons. Humans have taken over most of the lands where lions used to live. Hunters kill lions for their fur. And Maasai farmers hoping to keep their livestock safe also hunt lions.

When scientist Leela Hazzah moved to Kenya, she spoke to many Maasai, who felt frustrated that they were often left out of local conservation programs. Those conversations inspired an idea: What if Maasai warriors were hired to protect lions? Soon after, Hazzah created Lion Guardians. The group uses technology and Maasai tracking techniques to find and protect lions in the area. Today, 40 Lion Guardians protect more than 100 lions from illegal hunting.

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: Based on the information in the text, what are two reasons why there are so few lions today?
qti-choice-interaction.qti-simple-choice: Hunters illegally kill lions for their teeth and claws. This isn't a reason mentioned in the text. The text says, "Hunters kill lions for their fur," not their teeth and claws. Top tip! We can forget information only seconds after we read it. Go back to check the text for answers!

Farmers hunt lions to protect their animals. This is one of the best choices. The text says that "Maasai farmers hoping to keep their livestock safe also hunt lions." So one of the reasons why there are so few lions today is because farmers hunt them to keep their animals safe.

The Lion Guardians use technology and traditional Maasai tracking techniques. This isn't a reason why there are so few lions today. The text tells us that the Lion Guardians "protect lions." Protecting lions wouldn't make it so that there were fewer lions.

Humans have taken over many areas where lions used to live. This is one of the best choices. The text says, "There are a few reasons" why there are fewer lions than there used to be. It then explains, "Humans have taken over most of the lands where lions used to live." So there aren't many lions today because they don't have much space left to live in.

In 1950, about 400,000 lions roamed Africa, but today fewer than 40,000 remain. This isn't a reason why there are so few lions today. This tells us that there are fewer lions than there used to be, but it doesn't give a reason why that is.

qti-content-body.p: Excellent! You correctly identified the two reasons directly stated in the text: habitat loss due to human expansion and hunting by farmers to protect livestock.
Not quite. Reread the first paragraph carefully. The author explicitly lists three reasons for the decline in the lion population. Your two choices must match the reasons given in the text.
